abstract.text: This appendix has been provided by the authors to give readers additional information about their work. Supplement to: Puelles VG, Lütgehetmann M, Lindenmeyer MT, et al. Multiorgan and renal tropism of SARS-CoV-2. N Engl J Med.

body_text.text: 1 Table 1  page 3 Supplemental Table 2  page 4 Supplemental Table 3 page 4

Supplemental Figure Table S1 ). Clinical and laboratory information is provided in Table S1 . In a subset of patients with sufficient available clinical information, we also provide potential links between (1) number of coexisting conditions and organ tropism (Table S2) , and (2) renal tropism and history of chronic kidney disease (Table S3) .

In silico analysis of scRNA-sequencing data Publically available scRNA-sequencing data for human adult kidney was used from https://app.terra.bio/#workspaces/kcoincubator/COVID-19_cross_tissue_analysis (Muus et al. 1 ) for human fetal kidney from https://home.physics.leidenuniv.nl/~semrau/humanfetalkidneyatlas/, data accession Nr. GSM3143601 (Hochane et al. 2 ). Percentages of ACE2-, TRMPSS22-and CTSL-positive cells in different renal cell types were calculated (Fig S1) .

Quantitative RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 Tissue samples were systematically sampled during the autopsy procedure, including lung, pharynx, heart, kidney, liver, blood, and brain in a total of 22 subjects. For a second run of experiments, tissue samples from different parts of the kidney were dissected/microdissected in biologically representative compartments, including cortex, medulla, tubulo-interstitium, and glomeruli. These samples were then stored at 4°C in RNA later solution (ThermoFisher; AM7021-500ML). All tissue samples were grinded (Precellys 24, Bertin, Rockville, US) using 2ml tubes prefilled with ceramic beads (Precellys Lysing Kit) and 1ml RNA and DNA free PCR grade water. For RNA/DNA extraction 200µl of the grinded tissue lysate or whole blood was transferred to the MagnaPure96 (Roche, Mannheim, Germany). Automated nucleic acid extraction was performed according to manufacturers' recommendation with whole process control (Roche control Kit) and final elution volume was 100µl. For virus quantification a previously published assay was adopted with modifications using chimeric 2'-O-methyl RNA bases at the penultimate base of both primers (mG and mC) to reduce primer dimer formation 3 . Briefly the forward primer, 5´-ACAGGTACGTTAATAGTTAATAGCmGT-3 (400nM end concentration), 5´TATTGCAGCAGTACGCACAmCA-3´ (400nM end concentration) and probe 5´-Fam-ACACTAGCC/ZEN/ATCCTTACTGCGCTTCG-Iowa Black FQ-3' (100nM end concentration) were used. Primer and Probes were obtained from Integrated DNA Technologies (IDT, Leuven, Belgium). One-step RT-PCR (25µl volume) was run on the LightCycler480 system (Roche) using one step RNA control kit as master mix (Roche) and 5 µl of eluate. Ct value for the target SARS-CoV-2 RNA (FAM) was determined using second derivative maximum method. For quantification standard in-vitro transcribed RNA (IVT-RNA) of the E gene of SARS-CoV-2 was used. The standard was obtained via the European Virus Archive 4 . Linear range of the assay is between 1x10 3 and 1x10 9 copies/ml. Quantitative β-globin PCR was performed with commercial TaqMan primer set (Thermo-Fischer, 401846) and Roche DNA control kit. PCR was run on the LightCycler480 system. The amount of DNA was normalized using human DNA standard (KR0454). SARS-CoV-2 RNA levels in tissues were normalized to b-globin DNA to adjust for differences in tissue input.

Following renal autopsy, the tissue was transferred to RNase inhibitor (RNAlater®) and manually microdissected into glomerular and tubular fragments. Manual micro-dissection was performed in icecold RNAlater® under a stereomicroscope using two dissection needle holders as previously described 5, 6 . We provide SARS-CoV-2 RNA copies per cell in specific kidney compartments in Fig. S2 .

Viral RNA was detected in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded sections with the RNAscope® 2.5 HD Duplex Assay (Advanced Cell Diagnostics, Newark, California, USA) following the manufacturer´s instructions. Genomic plus strand RNA was detected with a probe targeting the S gene (RNAscope® Probe -V-nCoV2019-S #848561-C2). Probes for housekeeping genes were used to assess RNA integrity (GAPDH #442201; B2M #484661-C2) and unrelated probes targeting the hepatitis delta virus genomic and antigenomic RNA (#469771; #433471-C2) as negative controls (Fig. S3) . Viral protein was detected in formalin-fixed paraffin embedded sections using a protocol for indirect immunofluorescence as previously described 7 . We used two commercially available antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 detection: spike glycoprotein antibody [3A2] (Abcam, ab272420) and SARS-CoV SΔ10 within S2 domain protein (Genetex, GTX632604). In every round we included a negative control by incubating the samples only in secondary fluorescent probes without primary antibody (Fig. S4 ). An antibody against Nephrin, a podocyte specific protein, was used as a reference (Progen biotechnic; GP-N2). It is worth noting that these techniques were performed within the limitations of existing tissue preservation in autopsy samples (e.g. levels of autolysis, fixation and overall tissue preservation). Table S1 . This table summarizes post-mortem interval (PMI), number of coexisting conditions highlighting affected organ systems including chronic kidney disease (kidney), and laboratory findings, including urinary analysis, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and SARS-CoV-2 RNA copies per kidney cell.

In number of coexisting conditions (-) represents absence in the clinical records; NA: not available; # obtained with urinary stix and sediment, $ patient was on dialysis since 2014, & total SARS-CoV-2 RNA copies corrected for beta β-globin, <DT: below detection threshold. 1-2 1 (20%) 4 (80%) 1 (20%) 4 (80%) 1 (25%) 3 (75%) 3 (75%) 1 (25%) 3-5 4 (24%) 13 (76%) 4 (24%) 13 (76%) 12 (71%) 5 (29%) 5 (29%) 12 (71%)
With history of CKD 8 4 (50%) 4 (50%) Without history of CKD 10 1 (10%) 9 (90%)

The high presence of SARS-CoV-2 infection adhesion and facilitator genes throughout different kidney compartments is shown using an in-silico analysis of publicly available single cell RNA sequencing data. Data was retrieved from Muus et al. 6 and Hochane et al. 7 .
body_text.section: Fig. S1. SARS-CoV-2 infection adhesion and facilitator genes in renal cells

body_text.text: Panel A shows that SARS-CoV-2 is detected in random kidney samples containing both cortex and medulla and Panel B shows SARS-CoV-2 detection in all renal compartments, especially in kidney glomeruli; where TI represents the tubulo-interstitial compartment. RNA integrity was controlled with probes detecting mRNA of the two housekeeping genes glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) and b2-Microglobulin (B2M) in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues from kidneys and lungs. Probes detecting hepatitis delta virus (HDV) plusand negative strand RNA were used as negative controls in both lung and kidney. As an additional negative control, an archived kidney autopsy sample, negative for SARS-CoV-2, and a PCR negative kidney sample from a patient with confirmed positive SARS-CoV-2 pulmonary infection was probed for SARS-CoV-2 (+)strand RNA. Scale bar represents 50μm. In the top panel, we show positive detection of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in glomeruli (first row) and tubuli (second row) by indirect immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy in a patient with confirmed positive SARS-CoV-2 PCR in the kidney (first column), and double negative controls, including staining in tissue from a patient with PCR below detectable threshold (middle column) and incubation only with secondary antibodies (third column). Scale bar represents 10μm.
body_text.section: Fig. S2. SARS-CoV-2 is detected in all renal compartments
